text: was an old province of Japan in the area of Fukuoka Prefecture and Ōita Prefecture on the island of Kyūshū.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Buzen" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 96. Along with Bungo Province, it was sometimes called . Buzen had borders with Bungo and Chikuzen Provinces. The ancient capital city of the province was near Toyotsu, Fukuoka. Whitney, Willis Norton. (1889). A Concise Dictionary of the Principal Roads, Chief Towns and Villages of Japan, p. 177. ==History== In the Meiji period, the provinces of Japan were converted into prefectures. Maps of Japan and Buzen Province were reformed in the 1870s.Nussbaum, "Provinces and prefectures" at p. 780. ==Shrines and Temples== Usa-jinjū was the chief Shinto shrine (ichinomiya) of Buzen. "Nationwide List of Ichinomiya," p. 3 .
